p: SBTs are mostly set by companies in high-income countries, with mainstreaming in low- and middle-income countries seemingly far-off (Fig. 2). Yet, SBTs for scope 3 and the nature of global trade may offer a mechanism for increased uptake in lower-income regions. Dagnet et al. [50] present examples of a Western retailer (Walmart) and clothing brand (Levi’s) that have both engaged with suppliers in Asia as part of their scope 3 SBTs. Such engagements can result in suppliers committing to and, eventually, setting their own SBTs18. This highlights SBTs as a relevant research topic within the global value chain literature, which focuses on power asymmetries in inter-firm networks with multinational companies typically deciding the terms upon which inclusion into global value chains is negotiated [71–73].
